Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness, credibility assessment, document authenticity
Evidence_Assessment: Negative credibility findings, Personal Information Forms (PIFs), assumed document tampering
Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of refugee claims based on credibility
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Perceived inconsistencies, lack of corroborating evidence, assumed document alteration
Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires consideration of all evidence and notification of concerns
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider ordered PIFs, lack of notice regarding document authenticity concerns
Outcome_on_Merits: Claims dismissed without full evidentiary consideration
Decision_Maker: Member Fiorino, Immigration and Refugee Board
Review_Standard: Unreasonable findings, breach of procedural fairness
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Breach found: applicants not notified of concerns about document tampering
Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative law, IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms (implied)
Legal_Rule_Source: Federal Court jurisprudence on procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated; Board relied on negative credibility
Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted to new Board member
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claims with procedural fairness
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review under Federal Courts Act
Legal_Provision: Section 7 of IRPA, Section 57 of IRPA, subsection 3(1) of the Federal Courts Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 3(1), s. 57; Federal Courts Act s. 3(1)
Governing_Rule: Duty of procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
